description: ssh-copy-id — use locally available keys to authorise logins on a remote machine

global_flags.description: Forced  mode:  doesn't  check  if  the  keys are present on the remote server.  This means that it does not need the private key.  Of course, this can result in more than one copy of the key being installed on the remote system.
If the filename does not end in .pub this is added.  If the filename is omitted, the default_ID_file is used.
do a dry-run.  Instead of installing keys on the remote system simply prints the key(s) that would have been installed.
two  options  are simply passed through untouched, along with their argument, to allow one to set the port or other ssh(1) op‐ tions, respectively.

SFTP mode: usually the public keys  are  installed  by  executing  commands  on  the  remote  side.   With  this  option  the  user's ~/.ssh/authorized_keys file will be downloaded, modified locally and uploaded with sftp.  This option is useful if the server has re‐ strictions on commands which can be used on the remote side.
This option is for debugging the ssh-copy-id script itself.  It sets the shell's -x flag, so that you can see the commands being run.
